titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alpha Clerical Union records 1979.018
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-05-07 14:57:31 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The mission of the Alpha Clerical Union, founded in 1884, was to promote the "spiritual, professional, and social culture and enjoyment of its members." Limited to a total of nine members, the union consisted of ordained ministers of the Reformed Presbyterian Church. These records contain the organization's constitution, bylaws, roll of members, minutes, and financial accounts.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Brooklyn Clerical Union, date unknown.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single logbook. The entries in the book are generally in chronological order.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The mission of the Alpha Clerical Union, founded in 1884, was to promote the "spiritual, professional, and social culture and enjoyment of its members." Limited to a total of nine members, the union consisted of ordained ministers of the Reformed Presbyterian Church.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Alpha Clerical Union records, 1979.018, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of one logbook containing records of the Alpha Clerical Union, also known as the Alpha Clerical Club and the Brooklyn Clerical Union. The records contain the organization's constitution, bylaws, roll of members, minutes, and financial accounts.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
